Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Rental and utility assistance
Detail Description: These funds can be used for rental and utility assistance to states, territories, counties, and cities to help stabilize renters during the pandemic and help rental property owners continue to cover their costs.

Funding Source: ARPA
Agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Description: Funds for establishing, expanding, and sustaining public health workforces
Detail Description: These funds can be used to carry out activities related to establishing, expanding, and sustaining a public health workforce employed by state or local public health departments or non-profit, private, or public organizations with demonstrated expertise in implementing public health programs. Public health departments employ contact tracers, nurses, epidemiologists, community health workers.
source_name: CDC Disease Intervention Specialists Workforce Development Funding

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Funds for public transit agencies to avoid layoffs and service reductions
Detail Description: These funds help public transit agencies avoid layoffs and service reductions. These new resources, when combined with previous allocations through 2020, equal 132% of an urbanized area's 2018 public transit operating costs. In addition, this is available at a 100 percent federal share for operating expenses related to the response to Covid-19 (except for Capital Investment Grant funds).
source_name: U.S. Department of Transportation ARPA 2021 Allocations and Apportionments

Funding Source: ARPA
Program: Homelessness Assistance & Supportive Services (aka HOME-ARP program)
Agency: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Description: Supportive services, affordable housing, and homeless shelters
Detail Description: These funds can be used to finance supportive services and construct new affordable housing, and for the acquisition of non-congregate shelter spaces for people experiencing homelessness
source_name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Rental and utility assistance
Detail Description: These funds can be used for rental and utility assistance to states, territories, counties, and cities to help stabilize renters during the pandemic and help rental property owners continue to cover their costs

Funding Source: ARPA
Program: Homelessness Assistance & Supportive Services (aka HOME-ARP program)
Agency: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Description: Supportive services, affordable housing, and homeless shelters
Detail Description: Funds to finance supportive services and construct new affordable housing, and for the acquisition of non-congregate shelter spaces for people experiencing homelessness
source_name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Capital projects related to work, education, and health monitoring
Detail Description: Funds for capital projects directly enabling work, education, and health monitoring, including remote options, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Rental and utility assistance
Detail Description: These funds can be used for rental and utility assistance to states, territories, counties, and cities to help stabilize renters during the pandemic and help rental property owners continue to cover their costs
source_name: State of Illinois Executive Office of the Governor Governor's Office of Management and Budget

Funding Source: ARPA
Agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Description: Funds for establishing, expanding, and sustaining public health workforces
Detail Description: These funds can be used to carry out activities related to establishing, expanding, and sustaining a public health workforce employed by state or local public health departments or non-profit, private, or public organizations with demonstrated expertise in implementing public health programs. Public health departments employ contact tracers, nurses, epidemiologists, community health workers
source_name: CDC Disease Intervention Specialists Workforce Development Funding

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Funds for public transit agencies to avoid layoffs and service reductions
Detail Description: These funds help public transit agencies avoid layoffs and service reductions.
source_name: State of Illinois Executive Office of the Governor Governor's Office of Management and Budget

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Funds for airports for broad Covid-19 recovery
Detail Description: These funds provide economic relief to eligible U.S. airports affected by the prevention of, preparation for, and response to the Covid-19 pandemic.
source_name: State of Illinois Executive Office of the Governor Governor's Office of Management and Budget

Funding Source: ARPA
Program: Homelessness Assistance & Supportive Services (aka HOME-ARP program)
Agency: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Description: Supportive services, affordable housing, and homeless shelters
Detail Description: Funds to finance supportive services and construct new affordable housing, and for the acquisition of non-congregate shelter spaces for people experiencing homelessness
source_name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

Funding Source: ARPA
Description: Funds to assist homeowners with delinquent mortgage payments
Detail Description: This program provides relief for vulnerable homeowners. The law prioritizes homeowners who have experienced the greatest hardships, leveraging local and national income indicators to maximize intended impact. Funds can be used to make delinquent mortgage payments. States must request funds and will receive funds based on their unemployment rate, number of mortgages in foreclosure, and number of mortgages that are past due.
source_name: U.S. Department of Treasury Homeowner Assistance Fund Allocations

Funding Source: ARPA
Agency: Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity
Description: Programs supporting businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged entrepreneurs
Detail Description: This program includes: $1.5 billion for states to support businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged entrepreneurs; $1 billion for an incentive program to boost funding tranches for states that show robust support for these businesses; and $500 million to support very small businesses with fewer than 10 employees. This law will inject capital into state small business support and capital access programs, provide collateral support, facilitate loan participation, and enable credit guarantee programs.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Piloting new approaches to 911 call diversion
Detail Description: Improves the City's response to 911 calls by piloting new approaches to 911 call diversion, alternate response models, and establishing alternate destinations for patient transport
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Access and awareness for public support services
Agency: Chicago Department of Public Health; Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Community-based navigation resources for public services
Detail Description: Provides community-based navigation resources to ensure residents are aware of and have access to public services, including the creation of a 211 system
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Office of Budget and Management
Description: Grants for students and households to cover school supplies
Detail Description: Provides flexible grants for Chicago students/households to cover school supplies, food, and other essentials that are required for student support
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events
Description: Targeted relief for individual artists and cultural organizations not eligible for other federal relief programs
Detail Description: Targeted relief for individual artists and cultural organizations not eligible for other federal relief programs
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Neighborhood-scale broadband investments
Detail Description: Expands Chicago Connected by funding neighborhood-scale broadband and leverage City assets to increase broadband affordability in communities
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Commercial corridors and responsive neighborhood activation investments
Agency: Department of Planning and Development; Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection
Description: Grants and business support services to revitalize commercial corridors
Detail Description: Grants and business support services to revitalize commercial corridors and support new small business owners and local artists involved in beautification projects; also includes community programs to drive local participation in the planning process and workforce participation in community-driven development projects
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Economic development program promoting local ownership of community assets
Detail Description: Creates a new economic development program to promote local, democratic, and shared ownership and control of community assets; pilot investments in shared-equity models (e.g. worker cooperatives, housing cooperatives, community land trusts), giving historiclaly disinvested communities more accessible and sustainable pathways to building wealth
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Assistance for households that are unable to pay rent or utilities
Detail Description: Provides funding to assist households that are unable to pay rent or utilities
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Pollution and industrial health assessments
Detail Description: Invest in impact assessment capabilities for pollution and residential and industrial hazards in communities that drive inequitable health outcomes for residents
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Community-driven development near transit
Detail Description: Advance local housing, public health, climate resiliency and economic recovery goals by supporting community-driven development near transit to foster healthy, walkable, affordable, and accessible communities
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA
Program: Federal Aviation Administration Grants-in-Aid for Airports
Description: Airport capital expenditures and operating expenses
Detail Description: Funds for airport capital expenditures, airport operating expenses including payroll and utilities, and airport debt payments
source_name: Federal Aviation Administration Airport Rescue Grants Allocations

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Emergency funds and legal assistance for survivors of gender-based violence
Detail Description: Assists survivors of gender-based violence through emergency funds, legal assistance, prevention education, housing and other care coordination services
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Behavioral health services to support stable housing for high utilizers of emergency services
Detail Description: Provides behavioral health services to support stable housing for high utilizers of emergency services
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Assistance for individuals experiencing or at risk of homelessness
Detail Description: Assists individuals or households who are homeless, at risk of homelessness, and other vulnerable populations by providing housing, rental assistance, supportive services, and non-congregate shelter to reduce homelessness and increase housing stability across the country
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Rehousing and wraparound services for people at risk of homelessness and domestic violence
Detail Description: Provides funds for people at risk of homelessness, including those at risk of domestic violence, to access rehousing services and wraparound services en route to permanent housing solutions
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Expands workforce training opportunities for formerly incarcerated individuals
Detail Description: Expands workforce training opportunities for formerly incarcerated individuals to attain employment and other stabilization services
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Resources for initiatives and violence reduction initiatives
Description: Violence reduction and community safety programs
Detail Description: Funds a comprehensive set of programs including operational support and staffing for the CSCC, communications and marketing for violence prevention and reduction, expansion of resources for violence intervention programming and support for community groups
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events
Description: Emergency assistance funds for eligible venues affected by Covid-19
Detail Description: Emergency assistance funds for eligible venues affected by Covid-19
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Creates a new sobering center facility as an alternative to emergency rooms and jails for publicly intoxicated individuals
Detail Description: Creates a new facility to enhance public safety and health outcomes by providing an alternative to emergency rooms and jails for publicly intoxicated individuals to initiate recovery
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Planning and Development; Department of Business Affiairs and Consumer Protection
Description: Workforce opportunities in commercial development
Detail Description: Creates workforce opportunities for engagement along corridors to ensure safety, cleanliness, and local participation in commercial development processes
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Targeted financial and legal assistance for underserved residents
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services; Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection
Description: Financial assistance programs for underserved communities, including monthly cash assistance
Detail Description: Creates immediate financial assistance programs for underserved communities such as undocumented residents, domestic workers, and small community-based nonprofits providing safety net services; pilot a monthly cash assistance program for hard-hit, low-income households in need of additional economic stability; expand legal assistance programs through the Legal Protection Fund and Community Justice Initiative
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: A wealth-building program transferring ownership of City-owned land to neighborhood residents
Detail Description: Reactivates vacant City-owned land and build community wealth by streamlining environmental reviews and transferring ownership to neighborhood residents for community benefit
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Services and supports for victims of violent crime
Detail Description: Services and supports for victims of violent crime and their families, including mental health supports, crisis intervention, support with accessing crime victim compensation, housing, food, and more
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Workforce development programming and wraparound services
Detail Description: Provides workforce development programming, including apprenticeship, career services, and other wraparound support for those entering the workforce or new industries
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Interventions for young people involved in violent crime, both victims and perpetrators
Detail Description: Expands interventions for young people with violence involvement--both victims and perpetrators--that will include case management and services such as mental health, employment support, and other wraparound services
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Implementation of a new youth diversion model
Detail Description: Implementation of a new youth deflection and diversion model, including facility/space needs and social services
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Chicago Department of Family and Support Services
Description: Creates and expands youth career programs
Detail Description: Creates and expands a comprehensive portfolio of programs to connect Chicago youth with early career opportunities, as well as an expansion of the My CHI. My Future. Program to increase opportunities for out-of-school programming and education
source_name: City of Chicago ARPA Recovery Plan

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: 911 Alternative Model Study and Strategic Plan
Description: Develop a strategic plan on 911 alternative response models
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council will engage consultants to develop a report and strategic plan on 911 alternative response models for Cook County. This includes 1) a comprehensive analysis of Cook County's current 911 system, 2) best and emerging practices in putting in place alternative responses, and 3) recommendations and a strategic plan on how Cook County may move forward with a new model. The goal of this project is to develop a plan for a response system that both better responds with mental health and other emergency services that do not require a traditional law enforcement response, needs which have been exacerbated during the lengthy pandemic, and to prevent unnecessary involvement of individuals in the criminal justice system.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Develop a criminal justice report outlining strategies to minimize overspending
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council will engage consultants to review Cook County's criminal justice budgets and develop a report with 1) an overview of current spending; 2) an outline of duplicative efforts or overspending; 3) a strategy to make reductions in criminal justice spending and invest in community; and 4) best practices from jurisdictions that have successfully reinvested criminal justice dollars into public health and community resources.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Advancing equitable recovery in the Southland/building capacity in the Southland
Description: Small business growth programs
Detail Description: The Southland Development Authority (SDA) drives comprehensive, transformative and inclusive economic growth in Cook County’s South Suburbs. Funding will allow the SDA to continue to support the small business growth programs to advance key sectors.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Extension of broadband infrastructure into south suburban communities
Detail Description: The Chicago Southland Fiber Network provides gigabit broadband to government, education, healthcare, and businesses. Cook County will support the extension of the broadband infrastructure into south suburban communities with the highest Social Vulnerability Index (SVI) scores in the State of Illinois. Cook County will also add public WiFi access in certain anchor institutions, education institutions and government institutions that serve vulnerable communities.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Upgrade broadband infrastructure at all Housing Authority of Cook County (HACC) properties
Detail Description: This initiative will upgrade broadband infrastructure at all Housing Authority of Cook Countyowned (HACC) properties. Current network infrastructure can only support 2-3 users at a time and is inadequate to meet the needs of both staff and residents who use the communal computers. This upgrade responds to the increased need for Internet access among HACC residents and staff due to COVID-19 restrictions and will additionally address the digital divide by providing low-income residents access to high-speed Internet.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Development of an action plan on digital divide in suburban Cook County
Detail Description: To coordinate long-term digital equity work, Cook County will develop an action plan to evaluate where suburban Cook’s digital divide exists and outline solutions to cover gaps in broadband access, physical connectivity infrastructure, and financial barriers residents face when accessing digital devices and connections.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Support for residents behind on mortgage payments
Detail Description: The Emergency Mortgage Assistance Program will provide funds to support residents who are behind on mortgage, insurance escrow, and residential real estate tax escrow payments. The program will also fund additional housing services supports to offset foreclosure and further increase household stability.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Rental and utility assistance, as well as housing services to offset evictions
Detail Description: The Emergency Rental Assistance Program will provide funds to support residents who are behind on rent, utilities, and household expenses and will cover forward rent to support renter household stability. The program will also fund additional housing services and supports to offset evictions and further increase household stability. Cook County will administer this program in partnership with the Housing Authority of Cook County.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Fixed-Site Emergency Shelter for People Experiencing Homelessness
Description: Shelter services for people experiencing homelessness
Detail Description: The Bureau of Economic Development will support organizations within the Cook County Continuum of Care to stand up fixed-site shelter in 5-7 locations to provide health and safety to people in a housing crisis who cannot be diverted from homelessness. These organizations will also provide shelter services to ensure their experience of homelessness is short by reconnecting them to housing and other supports.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Hotel-based sheltering for people experiencing homelessness
Detail Description: The Bureau of Economic Development will continue the hotel-based sheltering approach implemented during the pandemic, when the existing PADS model of shelter with congregate shelter in rotating church basements was no longer viable

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Permanent Supportive Housing for People Experiencing Homelessness
Description: Creation of 250 permanent supportive housing units
Detail Description: Cook County will create 250 new units of permanent supportive housing, a nationally recognized best practice for ending homelessness. Permanent supportive housing is a housing model that pairs non-time-limited rental subsidies with individualized, intensive, supportive services to help households maintain independent living and housing stability.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Emergency re-entry voucher program for people leaving Cook County jail and transitioning into housing
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council will administer emergency re-entry vouchers to assist people leaving Cook County Jail in securing safe housing. Currently, approximately 1,100 people in Cook County are kept behind bars after their release date because they cannot find affordable housing.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Funding for violent gun crime investigation and prosecution
Detail Description: This request will assist the Cook County State's Attorney's Office in investigating and prosecuting violent gun crimes. The State’s Attorney’s Office will use funding to add Investigators to the unit to work with prosecutors (state and federal, law enforcement agencies, etc.) and other stakeholders to help ensure public safety in communities across Cook County.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Strengthening Chicago's youth juvenile justice collaborative expansion
Description: Violence-reduction and juvenile justice programming for youth at high risk of exposure to violence
Detail Description: This project aims to reduce violence and minimize justice involvement of youth who have experienced violence or trauma or are at high risk of exposure to violence. Services include trauma-informed care coordination for 500 justice-involved youth per year over three years, including youth on diversion (arrested for a felony or violent misdemeanor) or youth granted deferred prosecution. Services include intake, assessment, connection to evidence-based programming and pro-social services, emergency assistance, family support services, and postdischarge monitoring. In addition to providing care coordination and direct services for youth and their families, funds will support data tracking and analysis, continuous quality improvement, and developing an evaluation plan.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Funds for the Supporting Education and Employment Development (SEED) Program, a plea-diversion and case management program
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council will provide funds to sustain and expand the Supporting Education and Employment Development (SEED) Program, a 13-month pre-plea diversion program for individuals aged 18 to 30, charged with possession with intent to deliver or manufacturing/delivery of a substance. The program provides case management, educational services, trauma-informed and cognitive behavioral interventions, job readiness training, job development and placement, supported employment, and restorative justice activities. The successful completion of the program results in case dismissal and expungement at graduation.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Violence prevention and reduction grant portfolio
Description: Community-based services supporting justice-involved adults and youth
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council (JAC) will expand funding for community-based services supporting justice-involved adults or youth, and those at high risk of experiencing violence as either a victim or perpetrator. Services include direct street-level intervention, mentoring, basic needs assistance, educational and vocational programming, and behavioral health and wellness support.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Department of Public Health
Description: Expanding existing mental health and substance use services, and treatment and prevention programs
Detail Description: Expands existing mental health and substance use services, treatment, and prevention programs in priority communities in suburban Cook County in part through a community-based grants program in partnership with the Justice Advisory Council. Key areas of focus will include suicide prevention (including school-based screening), counseling and treatment, behavioral health workforce development, and youth-focused programs, including restorative justice and school discipline reform

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County State's Attorney's Office Gun Crimes Strategies Unit
Description: Expanding the Gun Crimes Strategy Unit's outreach efforts
Detail Description: The Gun Crimes Strategies Unit (GCSU) embeds Assistant State's Attorneys in six of the most violent police districts in Chicago. Expansion of the Gun Crimes Strategies Unit will allow the Cook County State's Attorney's Office to expand the reach and efforts of the GCSU in order to help combat the rise in violence and shootings within the City and the South Suburbs.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Funding for Healing Hurt People, a trauma-informed violence intervention program
Detail Description: Healing Hurt People (HHP) is a trauma-informed violence intervention program for survivors of urban intentional violence. HHP works to advance the notion that unaddressed psychological trauma is a key driver of the cycle of violence, fueled by the structural violence of racism and stigma. HHP Chicago's goals are to reduce re-injury, retaliation, and criminal justice involvement by having a positive impact on trauma recovery, mental health, and drug use, and help participants achieve independence, work, education, and create a strong future.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Department of Transportation and Highways
Description: Expanding a grant program for transportation infrastructure projects
Detail Description: Invest in Cook is an existing grant program that annually awards $8.5 million to communities to advance local transportation infrastructure projects that implement the priorities of the County's long-range transportation plan and support economic outcomes

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Department of Transportation and Highways
Description: Funding for electric vehicle charging stations, especially in areas with large service gaps
Detail Description: This initiative involves four components related to increasing access to electric vehicle charging stations throughout Cook County, focusing on where there are currently large gaps in service areas, primarily in the south and west suburbs, through installing 50 Level 2 charging stations, 10 DC fast chargers, 10 Level 2 streetlight charging stations and purchasing one allelectric bus and wireless charger installation to pilot at the Department of Corrections Campus.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Forest Preserves of Cook County within the Office of the President
Description: Community conservation projects in local forest preserves
Detail Description: The Forest Preserves along with corps partners will recruit and hire up to 282 adult corps members per year from Cook County who are currently unemployed or under-employed to conduct meaningful conservation work in their local Forest Preserve. Corps members will be deployed in teams of 6 to 10 participants and supervised by experienced Field Leaders who have the technical skills to train and supervise conservation work while providing soft job skills for those new to the work force. A minimum of 75% of participants will gain at least three advanced industry skill certifications.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Establishing and expanding apprenticeship programs
Detail Description: As a designated Apprenticeship Navigator by the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity, Cook County will support the establishment of new apprenticeships or expansions of existing apprenticeships in suburban Cook County. The Bureau of Economic Development will fund eligible partners and Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity intermediaries to sponsor and manage apprenticeship programs, conduct industry engagement, provide technical assistance to businesses, and support apprentices' progress.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Workforce developpment and community service programming in suburban Cook County
Detail Description: Cook County will provide support to workforce and training programs that offer young adults quality paid work experiences to explore career pathways in target sectors or provide opportunities for a “community service corps”. The County will also support the expansion of workforce development programs that serve hard to engage populations including people without stable housing, youth in care and graduates of foster care system, people with disabilities, returning residents, and pregnant and parenting youth. Program resources will support residents of suburban Cook County.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Lead pipe removal at Vera Yates Homes and Richard Flowers Home
Description: Removal of remaining lead water pipes at two Housing Authority of Cook County (HACC) affordable family housing properties
Detail Description: This initiative will remove remaining lead water pipes at two Housing Authority of Cook County (HACC) affordable family housing properties: the Vera Yates Homes in Ford Heights and the Richard Flowers Homes in Robbins. This funding will allow HACC to remove all lead pipes at each of these properties, preventing children living at these sites from suffering irreparable, life-long neurological damage associated with lead exposure, and provide all residents of these developments a healthier, safer living environment.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Lead, leaking, and obsolete service line replacement pilot program
Agency: Cook County Bureau of Economic Development
Description: Management for lead, leaking, and obsolete service line replacements in high-risk communities
Detail Description: Cook County will work in partnership with municipal water utilities to oversee and manage lead, leaking, and obsolete service line replacement across Cook County. This program will target high-risk communities, including improvements to individual homes, and high-risk facilities, including preschools, daycare centers, home daycare providers, group daycare homes, parks, playgrounds, hospitals and clinics.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Programs and services for domestic violence victims and survivors
Agency: Cook County Offices Under the President
Description: Grants for providers serving domestic violence survivors
Detail Description: The Offices Under the President will administer grants to providers that serve survivors of domestic violence. Domestic violence advocates have requested this funding to support legal resources, mental health resources, and rapid housing resources for domestic violence victims and survivors.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Law Office of the Cook County Public Defender
Description: Legal services for the Roseland/South Chicago and West Garfield Park/Humboldt Park communities
Detail Description: Provides robust legal services to two Cook County communities that have been disproportionately affected by COVID-19, incarceration, and gun violence--greater Roseland/South Chicago and greater West Garfield Park/Humboldt Park. The Community Defense Center will work predominantly with African American and Latinx communities, providing legal services, community empowerment, advocacy and education.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Stormwater management programs in high flood-risk communities
Detail Description: Cook County partnered with the Center for Neighborhood Technology to create a Rain Ready plan for the Calumet Corridor, which includes Blue Island, Calumet City, Calumet Park, Dolton, Riverdale, and Robbins and has a history of both disinvestment and flooding. The Department of Environment and Sustainability will put these six communities on a path towards greater resilience by implementing many of the recommended projects to improve stormwater management through green infrastructure and sustainable economic development.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Funding for community-based organizations to provide rental and security deposit assistance
Detail Description: The Justice Advisory Council will fund Cook County community-based organizations to provide rental assistance, security deposit assistance, and outreach counseling to justice-involved individuals. The initiative will also explore more effective housing strategies, partnerships and supports to connect these individuals to stable and permanent housing thus helping to reduce recidivism.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Small Business Assistance Program & One Stop Shop
Agency: Cook County Bureau of Economic Development
Description: Advising services, webinars, and recovery grants for small businesses
Detail Description: The Small Business Assistance Program supports a coordinated network of over 30 partners that provide one-on-one business advising, webinars, and recovery grants. New funding will further build the capacity of partners to deliver services, increase availability of services in suburban Cook, and support the establishment of a Cook County “One-Stop Small Business Service Center.”

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Bureau of Economic Development
Description: Grants to small businesses with less than 20 employees and early-stage businesses impacted by Covid-19
Detail Description: Grants to small businesses with less than 20 employees that continue to suffer from the impacts of COVID-19, as well as early-stage businesses formed since the onset of COVID-19. The grants will position businesses for growth and a sustainable path forward.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Stormwater management programs in high flood-risk communities
Detail Description: Cook County will provide funding to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (MWRD) to support stormwater management in communities that experience significant flooding. This funding will allow MWRD to expand beyond funding to include overall responsibility for stormwater management project implementation since local capacity constraints currently limit the existing program's impact.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Bureau of Economic Development; Cook County Equity Fund Taskforce
Description: Economic and community development planning
Detail Description: Cook County will identify high vulnerability communities and co-design a process to meet community-defined needs for economic development, community building, community safety, public health, education or social services. The County will support communities over a sustained period to ensure implementation and capacity-building, as well as helping attract additional public, private, and philanthropic resources.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Cook County Department of Veterans Affairs
Description: Establishing a fund to provide grants for community-based veteran service organizations and veteran-owned businesses
Detail Description: The Department of Veterans Affairs will establish a fund to provide grants to community-based veteran service organizations and veteran-owned businesses. The Veteran Grant Program will begin with a seed of $5 million for grants in the following areas: Program Enhancement; Capital Improvements; and Small Business Development.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Recurring monthly unrestricted payments to a to-be-defined set of residents for at least 12 months to improve participants’ long-term economic stability
Detail Description: The Cook County Guaranteed Income Program will provide recurring monthly unrestricted payments to a to-be-defined set of residents for at least 12 months to improve participants’ long-term economic stability. The Guaranteed Income Program builds on the demonstrated success of guaranteed income programs in other jurisdictions in increasing residents’ financial stability and improving their health outcomes. Cook County’s program will include a research evaluation component to help the County better understand participant impacts.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Cook County Residential Water Conservation and Energy Efficiency Program
Description: Utility bill cost reduction program
Detail Description: The program will increase housing affordability for residents by reducing utility costs. Specifically, the project identifies residents for home energy and water assessments and implement energy efficiency improvements and water conservation measures (such as window replacement, roof repairs, insulation, air sealing, HVAC improvements, LED lighting, energyefficient windows and doors, installing low-flow water appliances and repairing leaks).

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Water utility bill payment assistance
Detail Description: The Cook County Water Affordability Program will provide water utility bill payment assistance to help households suffering from income loss and mounting bills during the pandemic. The program will reduce uncollectable debt for municipal water utilities. The anticipated focus of the program is on communities with a high-water burden, meaning that the household spends a significantly larger portion of their income on the water and sewer bill.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Development of a Community Information Exchange (CIE) to enhance in-development 211 system
Detail Description: Cook County Legal Aid for Housing and Debt (CCLAHD) helps residents resolve eviction, foreclosure, consumer debt, and tax deed issues pre-court and during the court process. CCLAHD provides free legal aid, mediation services, case management, and connections for tenants and landlords dealing with evictions, property owners who are behind on their mortgage payments or property taxes, and creditors and debtors with issues related to consumer debt.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: Cook County Legal Aid for Housing and Debt
Description: Legal aid and case management services for residents facing eviction, foreclosure, consumer debt, and tax deed issues
Detail Description: The program will increase housing affordability for residents by reducing utility costs. Specifically, the project identifies residents for home energy and water assessments and implement energy efficiency improvements and water conservation measures (such as window replacement, roof repairs, insulation, air sealing, HVAC improvements, LED lighting, energyefficient windows and doors, installing low-flow water appliances and repairing leaks). This program will also serve as a jobs program by employing local residents.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Description: Purchasing and retiring medical debt of income-eligible patients in Cook County hospitals
Detail Description: Cook County will support the development of a Community Information Exchange (CIE) for suburban Cook County and the City of Chicago to enhance the 211 system already being collaboratively developed by Cook County, the City of Chicago and a range of partners. A CIE is an interconnected and linked network of health, behavioral health, human, and social service providers that share information and coordinate services so that an individual receives the whole person care they need to be healthy and thrive, regardless of how they initially enter services, creating a “no wrong door” access to the social and health services system.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Program: American Rescue Plan Capital Assets Program
Agency: Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity
Description: Support improvements and investments in commecial corridors and downtowns
Detail Description: To support improvements and encourage investment in commercial corridors and downtowns that have experienced disinvestment, particularly in communities hardest hit by COVID-19. Through this program, DCEO can fund projects that make these areas more attractive for private investment, generate short-term and long-term employment opportunities, and improve quality of life in the community through high-quality infrastructure and amenities.

Funding Source: ARPA State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds
Agency: Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity
Description: Funds for businesses for revenue loss recovery
Detail Description: For general business recovery and to offset losses during the pandemic, including a set aside for businesses that applied but did not receive funding under the Business Interruption Grant Program (BIG) and a set aside for business regrowth and renewal

Detail Description: Support for child advocacy centers managed by the Department of Children and Family Services

Detail Description: Creates new financing programs and tax incentives to support the creation and preservation of affordable housing in communities across Illinois

Description: Funding for Fifth Street Renaissance, a community organization providing education and outreach programs
Detail Description: Fifth Street Renaissance provides a variety of education and outreach programs, including HIV positive support groups, active street and community outreach, prison outreach, drug addiction outreach, and local school district outreach

Description: The Black and Gold Initiative provides mentoring, educational programming, and violence prevention programming for Black male high school students
Detail Description: The Black and Gold Initiative provides mentoring, educational programming, and violence prevention for black male high school students to attain educational excellence in the Champaign-Urbana area. The grant will support mentoring, education programing, and violence prevention.

Program: Low Income Household Water Assistance Program
Agency: Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity
Description: Assists low-income households with affordable drinking water and wastewater services
Detail Description: The Low Income Household Water Assistance Program will assist low-income households, particularly those with the lowest incomes and that pay a high proportion of household income for drinking water and wastewater services, by providing funds to owners or operators of public water systems or treatment works to reduce arrearages of and rates charged to low-income households for water and wastewater services.

Funding Source: CARES
Agency: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Description: Funds available to states, metropolitan cities, urban counties, and insular areas to respond to the Covid-19 pandemic. At least 70 percent of every grant must be expended for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income persons
Detail Description: Funds available to states, metropolitan cities, urban counties, and insular areas to respond to the Covid-19 pandemic. At least 70 percent of every grant must be expended for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income persons by providing housing, a permanent job, a public service, or access to new or significantly improved infrastructure. The remaining 30 percent may be used to eliminate slum or blighted conditions, or to address an urgent need for which the grantee certifies it has no other funding.
source_name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development CARES Act Supplemental Funding
